page.title: Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=January 2020}} {{about|European political party|the former European Parliament Group|Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe group|the transnational political alliance|Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe}} {{short description|European political party}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2020}} {{Infobox political party | name = Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party | logo = [[File:ALDE-Party-Logo-mitWeissUntergrund-Ausschnitt.png|200px]] | colorcode = {{Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe/meta/color}} | foundation = 26 March 1976as "Federation of Liberal and Democrat Parties in Europe" | ideology = [[Liberalism in Europe|Liberalism]]{{cite web|url=http://www.parties-and-elections.eu/eu.html|title=European Union|website=Parties and Elections in Europe|last=Nordsieck|first=Wolfram|year=2019|access-date=30 May 2019|url-status=live|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170608032858/http://www.parties-and-elections.eu/eu.html|archivedate=8 June 2017}}
[[Pro-Europeanism]] | headquarters = Rue d'Idalie 11,
1000 [[Brussels]], Belgium | international = [[Liberal International]] | website = {{URL|www.aldeparty.eu/}} | country = European Union | leader1_title = President | leader1_name = [[Hans van Baalen]] [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] | leader2_title = Group leader | leader2_name = [[Dacian Cioloș]] [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] | youth_wing = [[European Liberal Youth]] | think_tank = [[European Liberal Forum]] | europarl = {{plainlist|*[[European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party Group|ELDR]] {{small|(1976–2004)}} *[[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe group|ALDE]] {{small|(2004–2019)}} *[[Renew Europe|Renew]] {{small|(2019–)}}}} | colours = {{Color box|darkblue|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|lightblue|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|magenta|border=darkgray}} Dark blue, light blue, [[magenta]]
{{Color box|{{Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe/meta/color}}|border=darkgray}} Yellow (customary) | seats1_title = [[European Parliament]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|68|705|hex={{Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe/meta/color}}}} | seats2_title = [[European Council]] | seats2 = {{Composition bar|6|27|hex={{Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe/meta/color}}}} | seats3_title = [[European Commission]] | seats3 = {{Composition bar|5|27|hex={{Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe/meta/color}}}} | seats4_title = [[Lower House|European Lower Houses]] | seats4 = {{Composition bar|723|9874|hex={{Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe/meta/color}}}} | seats5_title = [[Upper House|European Upper Houses]] | seats5 = {{Composition bar|244|2714|hex={{Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe/meta/color}}}} }} The '''Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party''' ('''ALDE Party''') is a [[European political party]] composed of 60 national-level liberal parties from across Europe, mainly active in the [[European Union]]. On 26 March 1976, it was founded in [[Stuttgart]] as a confederation of national political parties under the name '''Federation of Liberal and Democrat Parties in Europe''' and renamed '''European Liberals and Democrats''' ('''ELD''') in 1977 and '''European Liberal Democrats and Reformists''' ('''ELDR''') in 1986. On 30 April 2004, the ELDR was reformed as an official European party, the '''European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party''' ('''ELDR Party''').{{cite web|url=http://www.eldr.eu/en/press-releases/european-liberal-democrats-change-party-name-alde-party-0|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130213054307/http://www.eldr.eu/en/press-releases/european-liberal-democrats-change-party-name-alde-party-0|url-status=dead|archive-date=13 February 2013|title=European Liberal Democrats change party name to ALDE Party | ALDE Party|publisher=Eldr.eu|accessdate=23 September 2013}} The ALDE Party is affiliated with the [[Liberal International]]{{Cite web |url=http://www.liberal-international.org/site/Co-operating_Organsisations.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=13 November 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113022549/http://www.liberal-international.org/site/Co-operating_Organsisations.html |archive-date=13 November 2013 |url-status=dead }} and a recognised European political party, incorporated as a non-profit association under [[law of Belgium|Belgian law]]. On 10 November 2012, the party chose its current name of ALDE Party, taken from its then-[[European Parliament]] [[Political groups of the European Parliament|group]], the [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group|Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe]] (ALDE), which had been formed on 20 July 2004 in conjunction with the [[European Democratic Party]] (EDP). Prior to the [[2004 European Parliament election|2004 European election]] the European party had been represented through its own group, the [[European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party Group|European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party]] (ELDR) Group. In June 2019, the ALDE group was succeeded by [[Renew Europe]]. {{as of|2019}}, ALDE is represented in European Union institutions, with 81 [[Member of the European Parliament|MEPs]] and four members of the [[European Commission]]. Of the 27 [[member states of the European Union|EU member states]], there are five with ALDE-affiliated Prime Ministers: [[Mark Rutte]] ([[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy|VVD]]) in the [[Netherlands]], [[Xavier Bettel]] ([[Democratic Party (Luxembourg)|DP]]) in [[Luxembourg]], [[Jüri Ratas]] ([[Estonian Centre Party]]) in [[Estonia]], [[Marjan Šarec]] ([[List of Marjan Šarec|LMS]]) in [[Slovenia]], and [[Andrej Babiš]] ([[ANO 2011|ANO]]) in the [[Czech Republic]]. Liberals are also in government in three other EU member states: France, [[Croatia]], [[Latvia]] and [[Lithuania]]. ALDE's think tank is the [[European Liberal Forum]]. The youth wing of ALDE is the [[European Liberal Youth]] (LYMEC), which is predominantly based upon youth and student liberal organisations but contains also a small number of individual members. LYMEC is led by Vedrana Gujic ([[Croatian People's Party – Liberal Democrats|HNS]], Croatia), who was elected for a two-year term as LYMEC President in May 2014, and counts 200,000 members. ==Structure== {{Liberalism sidebar |Organisations}} ===Bureau=== The day-to-day management of the ALDE Party is handled by the Bureau, the members of which are:{{Cite |} == Presidents == [[File:Johannes Cornelis van Baalen MEP 1 - Diliff.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Hans van Baalen]]]] * 1978–1981: {{flagicon|Luxembourg}} [[Gaston Thorn]] * 1981–1985: {{flagicon|Belgium}} [[Willy De Clercq]] * 1985–1990: {{flagicon|Luxembourg}} [[Colette Flesch]] * 1990–1995: {{flagicon|Belgium}} Willy De Clercq * 1995–2000: {{flagicon|Denmark}} [[Uffe Ellemann-Jensen]] * 2000–2005: {{flagicon|Germany}} [[Werner Hoyer]] * 2005–2011: {{flagicon|Belgium}} [[Annemie Neyts-Uyttebroeck]] * 2011–2015: {{flagicon|United Kingdom}} [[Graham Watson]] * 2015–present: {{flagicon|Netherlands}} [[Hans van Baalen]] == History of pan-European liberalism == {{main|History of pan-European liberalism}} [[File:ELDR logo.svg|thumb|150px|right|ELDR Party logo (2009–2012).]] Pan-European liberalism has a long history dating back to the foundation of Liberal International in April 1947. On 26 March 1976, the Federation of Liberal and Democrat Parties in Europe was established in [[Stuttgart]]. The founding parties of the federation were the [[Free Democratic Party (Germany)|Free Democratic Party]] of Germany, [[Radical Party (France)|Radical Party]] of France, [[Liberal Party (Denmark)|Liberal Party]] of Denmark, [[Italian Liberal Party]], Dutch [[People's Party for Freedom and Democracy]] and [[Democratic Party (Luxembourg)|Democratic Party]] of Luxembourg.{{cite book|author=Dimitri Almeida|title=The Impact of European Integration on Political Parties: Beyond the Permissive Consensus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oD7bKbo0FYEC&pg=PA102|year=2012|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-1-136-34039-0|pages=102–103}} Observer members joining later in 1976 were the [[Danish Social Liberal Party]], French [[Radical Party of the Left]] and [[Independent Republicans]], [[Liberal Party (UK)|British Liberal Party]], and [[Italian Republican Party]]. In 1977, the federation was renamed European Liberals and Democrats, in 1986, European Liberal Democrats and Reformists. It evolved into the European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party (ELDR Party) in 2004, when it was founded as an official [[European political party|European party]] under that name and incorporated under Belgian law at an extraordinary Congress in Brussels, held on 30 April 2004 the day before the [[enlargement of the European Union]]. At the same time the matching group in the European Parliament, the [[European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party (European Parliament group)|European Liberal Democrats and Reformists]] Group allied with the members of the newly elected [[European Democratic Party]], forming the [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe]] (ALDE) with a matching [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Group|ALDE Group in the European Parliament]]. On 10 November 2012, the ELDR Party adopted the name of the alliance between the two parties, to match the parliamentary group and the alliance. On 12 June 2019, the ALDE group was succeeded by a new, enlarged group [[Renew Europe]].{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.eu/article/emmanuel-macron-liberal-alliance-to-be-named-renew-europe/|title=Macron-Liberal alliance to be named Renew Europe|work=[[Politico]]|date=12 June 2019}} ===European Council and Council of Ministers=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Member !! Representative !! Political party !! Member of the Council since !!
